metadata.case_name: Appellant v. Respondent (Election Petition No. 40 of 1967)

facts.text: General election held in February 1967 for U.P. Legislative Assembly from Iglas Constituency. Appellant, respondent and four others contested. Respondent secured 10,705 votes more than appellant. Other candidates secured less votes than appellant.
Appellant filed Election Petition No. 40 of 1967 in Allahabad High Court challenging respondent's election on various grounds.
High Court dismissed election petition on May 23, 1968.
U.P. Legislative Assembly dissolved by President's Proclamation on April 15, 1968 under Article 356 during pendency of election petition.
Election petition presented to registry by advocate's clerk in immediate presence of petitioner.

Appellant challenged election on grounds including printing and publishing Exh. 7 pamphlet (issue 7), hiring vehicles for conveying voters (issue 8), and exceeding prescribed election expenses (issue 10). Most other grounds given up.
Evidence of PW 16 Mohan Singh regarding printing of Exh. 7 unreliable; he was signatory and changed sides.
Exh. D-23 voucher for printing two pamphlets on behalf of respondent; does not satisfactorily link to Exh. 7.
Witnesses claimed respondent distributed Exh. 7 pamphlets; evidence rejected by High Court.
Particulars of 12 vehicles alleged hired for conveying voters; arguments confined to Truck USK 503, Bus RJL 9729, and a tractor.
PW 45 Sukhbir Singh claimed hired Truck USK 503 from non-existent Achaltar Truck Operators Union Hathras; evidence false.
Evidence on tractor vague; no registration number, conflicting ownership; PWs 33 and 34 unreliable.
Bus RJL 9729 allegedly owned by Babu Lal of Jaipur (not examined); PWs 30,31,32 unsatisfactory.
Alleged excess expenses on vehicles, wheat, atta, sugar, ghee for workers; evidence and documents not creditworthy.

legal_issues.text: Whether election petition was maintainable as not properly presented.
Whether election petition abated due to dissolution of U.P. Legislative Assembly on April 15, 1968.
Whether Exh. 7 pamphlet was got printed and published by respondent (issue 7).
Whether respondent, agents or workers hired vehicles for conveyance of voters (issue 8).
Whether respondent's election expenses exceeded prescribed limit (issue 10).

petitioner_arguments.text: Election petition properly presented in substance by petitioner.
Dissolution of assembly does not render petition infructuous; challenges validity of election and corrupt practices.
Respondent got Exh. 7 printed and published; supported by PW 16 Mohan Singh, Exh. D-23, witnesses on distribution.
Vehicles (Truck USK 503, Bus RJL 9729, tractor) hired for conveying voters; supported by PWs 37,40,41,45,48,30-34.
Election expenses exceeded limit, including on vehicles and food for workers.

respondent_arguments.text: Petition not maintainable as not properly presented by petitioner.
Petition ceased to be maintainable due to dissolution of assembly.
Did not print or publish Exh. 7; Exh. D-23 relates to other pamphlets like Exh. A-154, A-155.
No hiring of vehicles; witnesses unreliable, changed sides.

court_reasoning.text: Petition properly presented in substance by petitioner via advocate's clerk in his presence.
Dissolution does not abate petition; Act exhaustively deals with abatement (only on death/withdrawal); purity of elections paramount; proceeding questions election validity, not membership.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No statutory provision for abatement on dissolution; Ghasi Ram v. Dal Singh supports continuation.

court_reasoning.text: PW 16 unreliable (changed sides, stooge); Exh. D-23 not linked to Exh. 7; distribution witnesses rejected; High Court findings on facts accepted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No satisfactory evidence respondent printed/published Exh. 7.

court_reasoning.text: Truck USK 503: PW 45 false (non-existent union); other witnesses lack basis. Tractor: vague, no details. Bus: owner not examined, PWs unsatisfactory. Complaints suspicious.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Faction spirit in election petitions; evidence unsafe.

court_reasoning.text: Vehicle and food expenses evidence not creditworthy; most items not pressed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reliable proof of excess expenditure.

holdings.text: Election petition maintainable; not abated by dissolution.
No abatement on dissolution; Act provides exhaustive grounds.
No proof of hiring vehicles for voters.
No proof of excess election expenses.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ghasi Ram v. Dal Singh and Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Dissolution of assembly does not end election petition.
Relied on old parliamentary practice not applicable in India.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates election petitions, presentation, trial, abatement, withdrawal; no abatement on dissolution.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure for trial of election petitions as nearly as may be.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed upholding High Court's dismissal of election petition. No corrupt practices or irregularities proved on surviving issues.

key_quotes.text: The purity of elections is of utmost importance in a democratic set-up. No one can be allowed to corrupt the course of an election and get away with it either by resigning his membership or because of the fortuitous circumstance of the assembly having been dissolved.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The law relating to withdrawal and abatement of election petitions is exhaustively dealt with in Chapter IV of Part VI of the Act. There is no provision providing for the dropping of an election petition for any reason other than those mentioned therein.
key_quotes.speaker: court
